figure.figDesc: Page image of Daily Dispatch, Volume 23, Number 58, page 2.

div3.head: Northern papers.
div3.p:
Our friends would greatly oblige us by sending any Northern papers they may chance to get in their possession to this office.
The public will thus receive the news at the earliest moment.

div3.head: The season.
div3.p:
We have rarely ever seen a season so well adapted to military operations as the present.
The weather is splendid, the air bracing, and the sun brilliant.
It is neither too hot nor too cold, but exactly tempered to the convenience of man and beast.
That our leaders will take advantage of it to complete our late victories, we do not doubt.

We have more than once had occasion to observe that September and October have been favorite months in American military annals.
In the first Revolution, the operations that ensured the capture of Burgoyne and his army were begun in September.
The two battles which crippled his force were fought on the 7th and 19th of that month, and on the 17th of October he surrendered at Saratoga.
Washington performed the long march which brought him from the banks of the Hudson to those of the York in September and October, and captured Cornwallis and his whole army on the 19th of October. The battle of Brandywine was fought on the 11th of September, and on this very day (8th September) Green fought the desperate battle of Entaw.
In the war of 1812, the battles of Lakes Erie and Champlain were fought in September; the one Sept. 10th, 1813, the other Sept. 11th, 1814, both on Sunday.
Brown made his famous sortie from Lake Erie on the 2d September, 1814. On the 12th of the same month the British army was repulsed in its advance upon Baltimore, and the next day the bombardment of Fort McHenry took place.
On the 8th of September, 1847, our troops gained a victory in front of Mexico, and on the 14th, (the anniversary of the entry of Jerusalem by Titus, and of the entry of Moscow by Napoleon,) they took possession of the city.
It is worthy of remark that the allies landed in the Crimes on the 14th September, 1854, and one year after, on the 8th of September, carried Sebastopol by storm.

Our leaders, no doubt, keep these mighty events in their mind while they are preparing to add new trophies to those of which the month of September is already crowned.
Of all the events to which we have alluded, that of the capture of Jerusalem was of course the most important.
It effected the entire overthrow of a people which God himself had selected, of all others, to be the repository of his law, and to whom, of all others, he had chosen to reveal himself as the God of the Universe.
It had been foretold sixteen hundred years before by the great Jewish lawgiver, in terms so exact that his words read more like history than prophecy.
The Saviour of mankind himself had announced the consummation as near at hand, not more than forty years before.
It was intimately connected with the proofs which establish the truth of Revolution, and therefore affected the eternal welfare of mankind.
The entry into Moscow was also of great significance.
It was the beginning of the end, so far as the fortunes of Napoleon were concerned.--But should our army push its successes so far as to enter Washington on the 14th, it will have accomplished a feat of far more memorable significance than any other of the events enumerated, save only the capture of Jerusalem.
It will have put the finishing stroke to the boasted Union, that fabric reared by our fathers in good faith, as a temple of freedom, and converted by Yankee rascality into a den of robbers.
We confess to a slight touch of superstition — a very slight touch indeed.
We make the acknowledgment because we believe all men — how anxiously soever they may strive to conceal it — have more or less of the same weakness.
We almost believe in lucky days, and have a very strong propensity to put faith in coincidences.
We will not say our troops will enter Washington on the 14th; but if they should do so, would it not be curious?

div3.head: Deserters.
div3.p:
The character of a deserter from a volunteer army is the meanest of all characters.
It implies not only treason, cowardice, but pretence and humbug, making the creature who commit it at once the most base and contemptible of mankind.
In a volunteer army, every man, as the term indicates, enters it of his own free will.
No man was obliged to enter that gallant host which is now contending to the death for the valor and independence of the Southern States.
No one was compelled to put on the habiliments of a soldier, and to receive, in that guise, the admiration and gratitude of the country.
The deserter from such an army is false to himself, as well as to his country, and an impostor as well as a traitor, who deserves an ignominious death, but is so contemptible that, at present prices, it would be a waste of powder and shot to shoot him.

Deserters from a Southern army are altogether beneath the moral status of the same sort of recreants in the Yankee army.
Many of the latter are mere mercenaries, most of them were forced into the service by their necessities, and all of them might desert in a body without injury to their homes, liberties, or any vital interests of society.--Not so deserters from the Southern flag.
As the prompting of cowardice, or love of ease, they expose all that makes life valuable to destruction; country, firesides, family, property, and their noble comrades, who, faithful to their trusts, are fighting the battles of the recreant hounds, who have left them to struggle and perhaps to perish under the mighty odds thrown upon their diminished ranks.

As contemptible and traitorous as the deserters, the military loafers and humbugs who, on one pretence or another, are dangling about hotels, and showing off in public places, or dodging about in obscure retreats in the rural districts.
The ladies might do some service to the State in banishing these holiday heroes with their fans, or giving them a leave of absence from their presence till they had fulfilled their duties to their country in their commands.
If such an admonition should not prove efficient, the Provost Marshal should be authorized to swing each of them to the nearest lamp post or tree.

div3.head: Proclamation by the President.

p.hi: To the People of the Confederate States:

div3.p:
Once more upon the pepsins of Manassas have our armies been blessed by the Lord of Hosts with a triumph over our enemies.
It is my privilege to invite you once more to His footstool, not now in the garb of fasting and sorrow, but with joy and gladness, to render thanks for the great mercies received at His hands.
A few months since, and our enemies poured forth their invading legions upon our soil.
They laid waste our fields, polluted our altars, and violated the sanctity of our homes.--Around our capital they gathered their forces, and with boastful threats claimed it as already their prize.
The brave troops which rallied to its defence have extinguished these vain hopes, and, under the guidance of the same Almighty hand, have scattered our enemies and driven them back in dismay.
Uniting these defeated forces and the various armies which had been ravaging our coasts with the army of invasion in Northern Virginia, our enemies have renewed their attempt to subjugate us at the very place where their first effort was defeated, and the vengeance of retributive justice has overtaken the entire host, in a second and complete overthrow.

To this signal success accorded to our arms in the East, has been graciously added another equally brilliant in the West.
On the very day on which our forces were led to victory on the plains of Manassas in Virginia, the same Almighty arm assisted us to overcome our enemies at Richmond, in Kentucky.
Thus, at one and the same time, have the two great hostile armies been stricken down, and the wicked designs of our enemies set at naught.

In such circumstances, it is meet and right that, as a people, we should bow down in adoring thankfulness to that gracious God who has been our bulwark and defence, and to offer unto Him the tribute of thanksgiving and praise.
In His hand are the issues of all events, and to Him should we, in an especial manner, ascribe the honor of this great deliverance.

Now, therefore, I, Jefferson Davis, President of the Confederate States, do issue this, my proclamation, setting apart Thursday, the 18th day of September, instant, as a day of prayer and thanksgiving to Almighty God, for the great mercies vouchsafed to our people, and more especially for the triumph of our arms at Richmond and Manassas in Virginia, and at Richmond in Kentucky; and I do hereby invite the people of the Confederate States to meet on that day at their respective places of public worship, and to unite in rendering thanks and praise to God for these great mercies, and to implore Him to conduct our country safely through the perils which surround us to the final attainment of the blessings of peace and security.
Given under my hand, and the seal of the Confederate States, at Richmond, this fourth day of September, A. D. 1862.
Jefferson Davis.
By the President:
J. F. Benjamin, Sec'y of State.

div3.head: Married,
div3.p: On the 3d inst., by the Rev. Philip Courtney, John S. Rady, Reg., of this city, to Miss Fannie Lindsey, daughter of the late Elijah Lindsey of Henrico county.

div4.p: In this city, on Sunday morning, Marian McMAHON, aged seven years and two months, daughter of T. and Margaret McMahon.
Her funeral will take place this evening, at 3 o'clock, at the residence of her mother, 22d and Main sts. The friends of the family are respectfully invited to attend.
On the battle-field, near Warrenton Springs, on the 26th of August, 1862, in Culpeper co., Va., Wm. H. Hambleton, a member of the Old Dominion Guard from Portsmouth, Va., in the 23d year of his age.

div4.head: Obituaries.
div4.p: How often, during the present contest, have we been reminded that "The paths of glory lead but to the grave."

With relentless hand, Death sweeps over the field of battle, destroying at once the fairest prospects and brightest hopes.
These reflections are peculiarly appropriate in announcing the death of Samuel R. Sizer, a private in company I, 6th Regt. Va. Vols, who fell at Manassas on Saturday, on the 30th of August, 1862. The deceased was the only son of Beverly J. and Susan Sizer, of Manchester, and had lavished upon him all the fondness and affection of devoted parents.
When the war commenced, then only 16 years of age, with the ardor of youth he asked permission to join one of the volunteer companies then organizing in his native town, which, after much urgent persuasion, his fond parents regrettingly granted.
He served faithfully at Norfolk, and following his company on its removal from that place he was with it constantly until he fell, shot through the head, at the glorious but bloody battle of Manassas.

To the parents and friends of the deceased, this is a severe blow.
As a son he was dutiful and affectionate; as a companion, he was kind and gentle; as a soldier, he was obedient and faithful.--While we tender to his bereaved friends our warmest condolence, we can give them no greater consolation than the suggestion that his death is the work of Him whose mercy endured forever.
[*] A Friend.
Died, at the residence of his brother, C. H. Ferrell, Halifax county, Va., on the 8th ult, of typhoid fever, Rawley W. Ferrell, in the 27th year of his age.

The ravages of the disease commenced July 26th, and in thirteen days he became a corpse.
So malignant was the disease that he was unconscious almost from the commencement.
He died in the service of his country.
He entered the cavalry service soon after the opening of the war, and nobly served the cause of Southern independence, sharing the dangers and toils of the energetic army of the Peninsula.
At the close of the battle of Williamsburg he received an injury which caused him to be sent to Chimborazo Hospital, where he was honorably discharged from the army, and entered upon the duties of clerk in one of the divisions of that hospital.
In this capacity he was serving when he went to visit his brother, alas!
but to die. He was a faithful, fearless soldier, and combined with his patriotic devotion, generosity of soul, social excellence seldom equalled, energy and activity of mind which promised a bright and useful future, and purity of character adorned by a profession of the religion of Jesus.
He has left these scenes of sorrow to enter the realms of eternal blise. [*] J. M. P.

div3.p:
Dr. R. S. Vest has removed his office to the corner of Main and 7th streets, where he may be found at all hours of the day and night when not professionally engaged.
Orders for him may also be left at the office of Clopton & Lyne, corner of Wall and Franklin streets.
Dr. Vest having resumed his practice in the city, notice is hereby given that parties who hire negroes from us are required to send for him in case of sickness.
se 8--2t Clopton & Lyne.

div3.head: Daily Union prayer Meeting.
div3.p: --Under the auspices of the Young Men's Christian Association, every Evening this week, at 5½ o'clock, in the United Presbyterian Church, corner of Franklin and 8th streets. Let all remember the "hour of prayer." se 8--2t

div3.head: Braxton's battery.
div3.p:
--For the information of those having relatives in this battery, I take pleasure in stating that I have reliably ascertained that no member of it was injured in the late battles.
W. Hargrave White.

div3.head: Notice to Drawers of notes due the Planters' Savings Bank, of Richmond.
div3.p: --All Notes held by the Planters' Savings Bank falling due on and after the 8th September, inst., can be paid at the office of the Treasurer each day, up to 2½ o'clock P. M. After that time application for all unpaid will be made at the respective Banks that they may be drawn payable at, A. A. Hutcheson, Treas'r.

div3.head: A Valuable Farm for Sale.
div3.p:
--I offer for sale the Farm lying in Dinwiddie county, known as Butterwood, within three miles of Wilson's Depot, on the South Side Railroad, thirty miles from Petersburg and adjoining the lands of Charles Young, R. J. Elms, and the Rev. R. B. Foster, containing by a recent survey, 1,332 acres, one third of which is cleared, and a fair proportion of this is Flat Land, the balance in original growth and Pines, of which there is a large quantity of building Pine.
This farm is well watered, and is regarded as one of the best in the county, besides well adapted to the growth of Wheat, Tobacco and Corn.
The improvements are all new, consisting of negro houses, brick chimneys, barns, stables, granary, and a comfortable overseer's house.
The locality is healthy.
The neighborhood good, and convenient to churches of all denominations.
I will take pleasure in showing the lands.

Terms--Accommodating, and possession given for seeding a crop of wheat.
Full possession at Christmas.
For further particulars address the subscriber at Blacks and Whites, Nottoway county.
se 8--6t* F. C. Williams.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p: --All persons indebted to the estate of Daniel N. Melton, dec'd, will make immediate payment, and those having claims against said estate will present them at once to the undersigned, properly authenticated.
Sarah E. Melton,
Executrix of Daniel N. Melton, dec'd.
Henrico county, Sept. 6th, 1862. se 8--6t*

div3.head: Fine cavalry Boots, Shoes.
div3.p:
--Received this day, at Belvin's Sewing-Machine Rooms, a large stock of English Cavalry Boots, heavy bottoms, well sewed.
This is the best Boot ever offered for service.
Several hundred pairs of high-quarter English Shoes, sewed, suitable for soldiers, citizens, or servants, with a large variety of Congress Galters, for ladies and gentlemen, direct from Europe.
Also, a large stock of misses' and children's, and servants'shoes, on hand.
We are determined to keep the best Goods that can be had and sell at the lowest price possible.
Store Belvin's Block, on 12th street. Citizens are politely invited to call.
se 8--6t*

He came on to Virginia some time in July last, and is supposed to have gone on to Gen. Stonewall Jackson's army.
I am in possession of important information for him, and will suitably reward any person who will be kind enough to let me know his whereabouts.

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--On the 3d of September, at the Nottoway Junction, a small Pocket-Book, containing one $100 note, one $50, two $20's and one $2 note — all Confederate money.
Also, a Ticket to Richmond, and a silver half dollar, and other papers — among them a passport for myself and wife to visit Nottoway county.
The finder will receive a reward of $50 by leaving the pocket-book and money with Mr. Jas. E. Griggs, at the Junction, or at this office.
[se 8--1t*] J. E. Pleasants.

div3.head: Lost--$10 reward
div3.p:
--On Thursday night, about eight miles below the city, on the River road, near the residence of Mrs. Childress, my Mule; is of medium size, light sorrel color; had on leather harness, without bridle.
Any one finding the same will receive the above reward on his return to Conrad & Crew,
se 8--ts On Basin bank, bet. 11th and 12th sts.

div3.head: Stolen
div3.p:
--From camp, near Gordonsville, about the 10th of August, a medium size sorrel Horse, four years old, white hind feet, star in forehead, and thin mane and tall.
I will pay a liberal reward for his recovery, or for any information that may lead to it. Address me, at the Dispatch office, or through the Post-Office, 56th Va. Reg't, Pickett's Brigade.
B. R. Doyle.

div3.head: Lost or taken by mistake
div3.p:
--From the packet landing, (mail line,) last Tuesday a week, the 24th of September, a small sole leather hand Trunk, very much worn, containing valuable papers, useful only to the owner.
A reward of $50 will be paid for its recovery and delivery to
Lt. L. Zimmer,
se 8--6t* C. S. Arsenal, foot of 7th st.

div3.head: Twenty dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed or stolen, from Camp Lee, on Saturday last, my bay Mare, about eight years old and about fourteen hands high.
Two or three of her lower front teeth are out, and she bears several trace and other harness marks, and is very broad in the chest.
She was either taken out or made her own escape from said camp (Capt. A. W. Gant's company of cavalry) on Saturday last.
The above reward will be paid for her delivery to Lieut. And. J. Rogers, at the office of Messrs. Bayly & White, corner of Franklin and 12th streets, or to myself, at Camp Lee.
se 8--3t* John Blossingham.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--A large dark brindle Cow, with large horns, has broken into my premises several times within the last six or eight months, and as no one claims her in my neighborhood, she may possibly belong to some one in the city.
She gives no milk.
The rightful owner will come after her, prove property, and take her away.
Jas. T. Sutton, Jr.,
se 8--3t* Near Westham Plankroad.

div3.head: Strayed or stolen
div3.p: --On Friday, 5th inst., a dark brown and white buffalo Cow Calf, with a leather strap around her neck with a ring attached, for which I will pay a liberal reward if left at my house or information so that I may get her. Information can be left at Rham's foundry, also.
Robert Chandler,
se 8--3t* Laurel street, Belvidere Hill.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--Came to Mrs. C. F. Temple's farm, in Chesterfield county, five miles below Richmond, during the month of July, a light brown Mare, with black mane and tail.
Said mare was in very poor condition.
The owner can get her by proving property and paying charges.
se 8--3t*

div3.head: Found
div3.p:
--On Thursday morning, a Bull.
Any person giving the proper marks will receive the beast from Michael Shannon, at the corner of 17th street and Grace, near the Old Market.

Came to my House, some ten days since, a boy, about 17 or 18 years old. He calls himself Spencer, and says that he belongs to a man by the name of Gay Walton, of Hanover, and says that the Yankees have taken possession of his matter and his farm and some four or five others of his servants, and the reason that they did not take him, he was not at home.
The boy is deformed in both knees and walks very wide, with his feet nearly square out. He is a very good boy to work, having volunteered himself to work, so as to be taken care of. He may be a runaway so far as I know.
The owner can get him by application to
Philip Snoddy, of Columbia,
se 6--2t* Fluvanna county, Va.

div3.head: Estrays.
div3.p:
--Left my farm, near Broad Rock, Chesterfield county, about a week ago, two mare Mules--one a black, the other a brown; both of medium size.
Twenty dollars will be paid if delivered at my farm, or at my office.
Odd Fellows' Hall.
se 6--3t* S. R. Fondren.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--Came to my house on the 25th of July, on the Darbytown road, eight miles below Richmond, a sorrel Stud-Horse, in very low order.
The owner will please come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away.
se 6--3t* M. Harvey.

div3.head: Lost--$5 reward.
div3.p:
--Lost, yesterday evening, my free papers.
They were in a leather pocket book.
The above reward will be paid on their return to this office.
se 6--3t*

div3.head: Lost
div3.p:
--Ten Mules, between Petersburg and Richmond, about two weeks ago. A liberal reward will be paid for them if left with the Quartermaster, at Richmond.
The mules are branded "C. S." se 6--3t*

div3.head: Taken up
div3.p:
--On the 3d inst., near Fairfield Race Course, a sorrel Horse, sixteen and a half hands high, with four white feet.
The owner will come forward, prove property, pay charges, and take him away, or he will be dealt with according to law. Also, one Horse lost, nearly of the same size and color.
Wm. Rose,
se 5--3t* Head of 17th street.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward.
div3.p:
--Strayed from Mr. Charles Hanes's, in Henrico county, near the city, two red Cows, both with white spots in their faces; one had on a bell.
A reward of $10 will be paid for their delivery to the subscriber in Richmond, on 7th, between Clay and Leigh streets.
se 1--1m* John A. Mosby.

div3.head: Estray.
div3.p:
--Came to my house, about the middle of July, a small, brindle buffalo Cow, which the owner can get by proving property and paying charges.
W. H. Baugh,
se 5--3t* Midlothian Coal-Yard.

div3.head: Runaways.
div3.p: --The following slaves ran away from the Piedmont Railroad, at Danville, on the 3rd inst.:
Henry; black, about 35 years old, has several whip marks — was recently bought of John King, of North Carolina.
Spencer — hired of David Hotly, Chowan county, North Carolina.
Joe and Tom — hired of Mr. Roberts, Gates county, North Carolina.

A reward of $25 will be paid for Henry if taken within the State, or $50 if taken in another State, and the legal reward for the hirelings upon delivery to me at Danville.
E. D. Wilburn,
Sup't first section Piedmont R. R.,
se 8--ts Danville, Va.
Greensboro, N. C., papers will copy.

div3.head: Ten dollars reward
div3.p:
--Will be paid for my boy John, who left my farm, in Henrico, on Tuesday night last.
He is about five feet six inches high, dark complexion, has a defect in one eye, and several scars on his face, from a burn when a child.
I think it probable he is lurking about the city.
se 8--3t* Simon Gouldin.

div3.head:
General Hospital, no. 25,
Main and 28th streets.
div3.p:
Owing to the recent establishment of this Hospital, both supplies and funds are limited.
The Surgeon in charge would be most grateful for any contribution that would add to the comforts of its inmates.
Wm. R. Howle,
se 8--3t* Steward.

He is a splendid horse for an officer.
Any one in want of such an animal can see him at the stables of Messrs. Davis & Hutcheson, on Franklin street. Call early.

Encouraged by the unlimited success of their first spectacular production, "Beauty and the Beast," the management have, with much care and expense, prepared fully in every detail the interesting and excruciatingly funny Spectacle from the Oriental Tales, entitled the Arabian night's Entertainments of the Forty Thieves;
or, the Robber's Cave of the Black Forest!

the production of this great melee-dramatic romance has called into requisition every resource of the Theatre, and will be placed upon the Stage perfect in every respect, and in a style of Unexampled Splendor, which will rival any production of the kind attempted in America.
New Scenery by our artist, J. O. Goode, Esq.
New Dresses by Mrs. Lewis and assistants.
New Properties by E. Lewis and J.
T. Raymond. Mechanical Effects, Tricks, Transformations, &c., by R. D. Mundin and assistants.
the Music!

full and complete, has been Arranged by Professor Loebman, and will constitute one of the attractive features of the Spectacle, abounding with Songs!
Durtt! Choruses! Marches, &c.
the whole Play

Replete with Tableaux, Marches, Combats.
Songs, Dances, &c., &c.
Arranged under the direction of the Stage Manager, Mr. J. W. Thorpe.
the Ballet
under the supervision of the accomplished danseuse, Miss Mary Partington.
Previous to the Spectacle each Evening, a Favorite Farce.
Monday Evening, Sept. 8, 1862,
will be presented for the first time the grand Oriental Spectacle of the Forty Thieves!
with the following powerful and admirable cast:

list.item: Cassim Baba, a rich Merchant...Z Moreland.
Ali Baba, a poor Wood Cutter...C H Morton.
Abdallah, Captain of the Robbers...J W Thorpe.
Orcobrand, Enchanter of the Black Rocks and Protector of the Robbers...J Harrison.

div3.p: Fairy of the Lake, Protectress of All Baba, Miss M Estelle.
[With an auxiliary aid, improved and augmented.]
The evening's entertainment will commence with the favorite farce of State Secrets; or, the Tailor of Tamworth.
For synopsis of Scenery, Incidents, Dances, Music, Combats, &C., of the Forty Thieves!
See the elaborate programme of the evening.

div3.head: Dissolution.
div3.p:
--The concern of Cosby & Anderson, is this day dissolved.
All persons indebted to the concern are requested to make payment to me, and those having claims against the concern will present them for settlement.
The name of the firm will be used it, liquidation only.
Peter G. Cosby.

div3.head: Notice.
div3.p:
--In answer to the above card, it is quite sufficient to say that nearly a whole day before it was published, neither Mr. Cosby nor myself had any power rightfully to control the partnership concerns.
Judge Meredith on Tuesday morning, awarded an injunction (of which Mr. Cosby had private but actual notice, and which has only awaited the return of the clerk to town to be regularly served on him) to restrain him from doing the very thing which he proposes to do, and which will probably confide our affairs to other hands.
If the public have any concern in the matter, they will most likely wait to see whether Mr. Peter G. Cosby or a Circuit Court injunction is the stronger.
I forewarn persons from paying him any debts, or having any transactions with him touching Cosby & Anderson's affairs.
se 4--5t* Jno. H. Anderson.

div3.head: Confederate States of America--a proclamation.
div3.p: --The undersigned, having re-opened his office, most respectfully announces to the public that he is now ready to receive orders for--
Official Hand and Block Seals;
Dies of every description, on steel or brass;
Maps of Battles and Battle fields;
Invitation, Wedding and Visiting Cards;
Door Plates, Stencil Plates, and Marking Plates;
Letters for military caps;
Ornaments for caps generally.

Seals engraved on any metal.
The undersigned is prepared to do engraving on any metal, on steel, brass, copper, gold, and silver.
He is ready to do all work in the line of an engraver.
J. Baumgarten,
General C. S. Engraver, at S. Sutherland's Gun Stere, 123 Main street. au 28--1m*

div3.head: By James M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
div3.p:
Valuable and well-located Brick Dwelling, on the South side of Franklin, between 3D and 4TH streets, at Auction.--We will sell, upon the premises, on Monday, the 15th day of September, commencing at 5 o'clock P. M., the valuable and well-located Brick Dwelling, located on the south side of Franklin, between 3d and 4th streets. The Dwelling is nearly new, has eight rooms, besides servants' accommodations.
The premises are supplied with gas and water, and the whole nicely finished.
This property is located in the most desirable portion of the city, is convenient to business, and worthy the attention of those desiring to secure a pleasant residence.

Terms.--One third cash; the balance at 1 and 2 years, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed, or, if preferred, the purchaser can pay the entire purchase money in cash.
James M. Taylor & Son,
se 8 Auctioneers.

div3.head: Four acres Valuable Land, on Elmwood and Dover streets, town of Sidney, at Auction.
div3.p:

This is considered to be as valuable property as can be bought in that improving part of the suburbs, and we call the particular attention of capitalists and others thereto.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 8 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.

Two excellent Framed Tenements on Pleasants street, Union Hill, at Auction.
We will sell upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 9th day of September, commencing at 5 ½ o'clock P. M., two excellent framed Tenements, located on Pleasants street, Union Hill, occupied respectively by Mr. Collier and Mr. Tyler.
They contain four good rooms each, with closets, two story kitchen, and a well of superior water.
These tenements are in first-rate repair, having been quite recently erected.
The lots front 31 by 130 feet each, to an alley.
Terms--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 8 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
Valuable Farm of 340½ acres in Hanover county, 10 miles from Richmond, and 2 miles from Atlee's Station, together with the Personal Effects thereon, for Sale at Auction.--At the request of George T. Booker, Esq., we shall sell at public auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 16th Sept., 1862, at 11 o'clk A. M., (if fair; if not, the first fair day thereafter,) the valuable Farm located as above, called Laurel Grove, containing 340¼ acres, of which about two-thirds are open lands, in good heart, and the remainder in pine and oak woods.
The buildings on the place consist of a good brick dwelling, together with kitchen, stable, barn, &c. Around the dwelling and in front of it, are some fine shade trees and a large quantity of handsome cedars.
A well of pure water in the yard and an ice house within 100 yards of two ponds.

After the sale of the land, all the personal effects on it will be sold, consisting of a pair of oxen, wheat straw, hay, wheat reaper, wheat machine and farming implements.
Possession given immediately.
Terms.--One third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for bonds, bearing interest, half yearly, secured by a trust deed, with liberty to the purchaser to pay all the money in cash at his option.
Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

P. S — The foregoing farm can be treated for at private sale.
se 8

Eighty acres of Beautiful and Highly Attractive Land, on the North Side of a Continuation of Grove Street, in Sidney, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 9th September, 1862, at 5 o'clock P. M., 80 acres of Land, beautifully situated, located as above, adjoining the cottage of Mr. L. S. Squires.
It will be sub-divided into seven Lots of about 10 to 16 acres each, fronting on Grove street, according to a plat and survey to be shown at the sale.
All of these Lots, (with the exception of one, on which there is about 8 acres of woods,) are highly improved, and on one of them there is a small framed dwelling.
These Lots are admirably adapted to market gardens or suburban residences.
They are located in the most improving part of the county, where real estate is in good demand.

Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

P. S.--At the same time, will be sold a Kiln containing about 50,000 to 100,000 Bricks.
se 6

div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Tuesday, the 9th September, 1862, at 5 o'clock P. M., the very neat and beautiful cottage residence located as above, now in the occupancy of Mr. T. P. Strider, with four acres of land attached thereto, being the same recently in the occupancy of Mr. Stevenson.
The cottage and all the out buildings have been erected in the past two years, and are not only very ornamental, but remarkably we 1 arranged, and quite commodious.
Possession given 8th October next.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 1 and 2 years, for negotiable notes, interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 5 Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

Large Framed Tenement on Carrington street, near to 18th street, for Sale at Auction. --Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Wednesday, 10th of September, at 4½ o'clock P. M., the large and beautifully located residence of Mr. Thos. E. Matthews.
The lot has a front of 80 feet, and a depth of 165 feet, and commands a fine view of Richmond.
The house has eight rooms, including the basement.
On the lot is a well of fine water.
Possession given in a few days.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
se 2 Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

div3.head: Small Framed Tenement on the North side of Broad St., nearly opposite to Richmond College, for Sale at Auction.

The house contains four rooms.
The let has a front of 34 feet and a depth of 400 feet, to the railroad, and has on it a good well of water.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance in six and twelve months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
se 6 Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.

div3.head: Two Framed Tenements on the North side of Broad street, a few hundred yards West of the corporation line, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Thursday, the 11th September, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., two framed tenements, located as above, one occupied by Mr. Richard Rogers, and the other by Henry Boregar.
One of them is kept as a grocery store, and is considered a good business stand.
The lot has a front of 30 feet, and a depth of 146 feet to a wide alley.
Terms.--One-third cash; balance at six and twelve months, for negotiable notes, interest added, secured by a trust deed.
se 6 Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.

div3.head: Valuable Little Farm, of 55¼ acres, on the Meadow Bridgeroad, two miles Northeast of Richmond, for Sale at Auction.
div3.p:
--At the request of Mrs. Catharine Prentis, we shall sell at public auction on the premises, on Friday the 12th September, 1862, at 5 o'clock P. M., the valuable Farm locate as above, now occupied by her, adjoining the land of Messrs. Fendall Griffin, Garland Hanes, Jr., and others.
It contains 55¾ acres, of which about acres are well set in oak woods, the balance cleared and in excellent condition, of which 1 acres are well set in clover.
The improvements are nearly new, consisting at an excellent dwelling house and the usual out-buildings, all in good order, and a well of fine water in the yard.
The land is well suited for a market garden.
The neighborhood is good, and the place is remarkably healthy.

Terms--At sale.
Possession given 15th October next.
Goddin & Apperson.
se 3 Auctioneers.

Commissioners' Sale of 220 1-6 acres of Valuable Land, in Henrico county, nine miles above Richmond, on the Richmond and Charlottesville Plankroad, and within 100 yards of the Richmond and Fredericksburg Railroad.--By virtue of a decree of the Circuit Court of Henrico, pronounced on the 1st of May, 1862, in the case of Ryall, &c., against Ryall, &c., the undersigned Commissioners will expose to sale, by public auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 15th of September, 1862, at 11 o'clock A. M., (if fair; if not, the first fair day thereafter,) the Tract of Land of which the late John B. Ryall died seized, located as above, adjoining the lands of Messrs. James S Ryall, William.
Taylor, and Aug. Hopkins, containing, by a recent survey, 220 1-6 acres, of which 99½ acres are cleared land, having thereon a frame.
Dwelling and some out houses, all of which are on of repair.
The remaining 120¾ acres are heavily set in wood and timber, and are within 100 yards of the railroad, so that the wood can be brought to Richmond at a cheap rate.
It is believed that the wood land will average forty cords to the acre.
Terms.--One third cash; balance at 6, 12, and 18 months, for bonds bearing interest, secured by good personal security, and title retained until all the purchase money is paid.
Edmund T. Redd, Comm'rs.
Peter M. Ryall, Comm'rs.
Sale by Goddin & Apperson. au 26

Two large Brick Tenements on the East line of 23d street, between Main and Franklin streets, for Sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Saturday, the 13th of September, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., those two large and well-built brick Tenements located as above, occupied respectively by Mr. W. F. Hord and Mr. Neil McCurdy, Jr. Each tenement has ten rooms besides brick kitchen, and both remarkably well built.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at one and two years, for negotiable notes, interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 6 Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.

div3.head: Valuable real estate for Sale, in Albemarle county, Va.
div3.p:
--Under the directions of the late Thos. F. Lewis, dec'd, I shall, on Tuesday, the 9th of September next, (if fair; if not, the next fair day thereafter,) offer for sale the Farm of the deceased.
It contains about three hundred and fifty (350) acres, about fifty of which are in original forest.
It lies in the county of Albemarle, eight miles from Charlottesville, seven from the University of Virginia, and one mile from Ivy Depot, on the Virginia Central railroad; is within two miles of Bloomfield Academy, and in convenient distances of the churches of the various denominations, manufacturing miles, and blacksmith's shops and is located in one of the most desirable neighborhoods in the county.
It has all the buildings necessary for the convenience of a family and the use of a farm.
It is well adapted to the growth of corn, wheat, and tobacco.
Possession for seeding a crop will be given in sedately, and fall possession on the 15th of December next.
The terms will be made know, on the day of sale, and will be liberal.
Any communications with reference to this property addressed to the undersigned will receive prompt attention.
My Post-Office is Ivy Depot, All marle county, Va. (Signed) John H. Lewis,
au 23--tds Ex'or of Thos. F. Lewis, dec'd.

div3.head: For Sale at public Auction.
div3.p:
--On Thursday, the 11th September, 1,200 acres valuable Land, mostly of original growth, situated in Goochland county, forty miles from Richmond, within one mile of the James river, adjoining the farms of Mr. Thos. Bolling and William R. Fleming, being a part of the farm of the late Wm Salmon.
About one-half the land is cleared.
The buildings are in good order.
The water on the place is as good as any in the State, besides a very fine mineral spring of sulphur water.
The neighborhood is excellent — there being no better society in Virginia.
Any one wishing one of the most desirable locations on James river, will do well to purchase this place.
Any information can be had by applying to Eugene B. Salmon, Pemberton P. O., Goochland county, or to Wm. L. Salmon, at No. 117 Main street, Richmond, Va. The sale will come off on the day appointed, without regard to weather.
Eugene B. Salmon,
au 13--1m* Ex'r of Wm. Salmon, dec'd.

div3.head: By Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
div3.p: Seven Building Lots on the East side of Hancock street, between Clay and Leigh streets, and near to Buchanan Spring, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises, on Monday, the 8th day of September, commencing at 5½ o'clock P. M., seven very pretty Building Lots, located on the east side of Hancock street, between Clay and Leigh. They front about 30 feet each, and run back 160 feet. Upon one of the lots is a small framed house, occupied by Charles Hartman.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at six and twelve months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 6 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.

A Neat Framed House and Lot, on the South side of Leigh street, near to Buchanan Spring, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises, on Monday, the 8th day of September, commencing at 5 o'clock P. M., a very neat framed house, on the south side of Leigh st., near Buchanan Spring, and adjacent to the residence of John W. Lee, Esq. It contains several good rooms and a small kitchen, and is now occupied by C. Schabtach.
The lot fronts 40 feet, and runs back 220 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 6 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.

div3.head: By Goddin & Apperson, Auct's.
div3.p:
Beautiful Lot on Navy Hill on the East line of 5th, between Baker and Duval sts., for sale at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, on the premises, on Monday, the 8th of September, 1862, at 5 o'clock P. M., a most beautiful Lot located as above, opposite the residence of Rev. Mr. Hoyer, fronting 50 feet, running back 122 feet to an alley 16 feet wide.
This Lot is in a part of the city where real estate is much sought after.
Terms.--One-half cash; balance at 4 months bearing interest.
se 3 Goddin & Apperson, Aucts.

div3.head: Trustees' Sale of Valuable real estate at the Corner of Clay and 4th streets.
div3.p:
--As trustees in a certain deed of trust, dated 25th of April, 1861, duly recorded in Richmond Hustings Court on the 7th of June, 1861, in Deed Book No. 77, A, page 73, we shall sell at public auction, for cash, on Monday, the 8th of September, 1862, at 4½ o'clock P. M., on the premises, (if fair; if not, the first fair day thereafter,) a portion of the real estate conveyed by the said deed of trust, viz: A lot fronting 65 feet on the south side of Clay street, running back at right angles 100 feet to an alley, and bounded on the east by the west line of 4th street. The title is believed to be perfect, but the trustees will convey with the usual special warranty.
This is justly regarded as a most valuable lot, and is in an improving part of the city.
W. Goddin, Trustees.
au 29 J. L. Apperson, Trustees.

div3.head: By Richard Cauthorn, Auct.
div3.p: 20,000 Pounds of Bacon at Auction.--On Monday, 8th instant, at 10 o'clock, at my store, I will sell at auction, on account of whom it may concern--
20,000 lbs. Bacon, but little damaged,
5 bbls. Bacon Oil,
Crackers and Cakes,
Also--40 bbls. Butter and Soda Crackers, and 10 bbls. Sugar Cakes.

Also — A lot of Hardware, consisting of Pitchforks.
Shovels, Spades, Hames, 15 gro. Gimblet Screws, Hinges, &c.
Cigars.--10,000 Cigars, of various brands.
Shoes.--15 dozen pairs ladies' Galters, Buskins, boys' Shoes, &c.

Also — Salt.
Soap, Ground Coffee, Tobacco, Butter, Vinegar, &c.
se 5 R. Cauthorn, Auct.

div3.head: By Redwood & Keach, Auctioneers,
div3.p: Large Sale of Furniture, Kitchen Utensils, Cooking Stoves, Tobacco Butter, Coffee, &C. --On Monday, September 8th, commencing at 10 o'clock, we will sell a large quantity of Furniture, &c., consisting of--
Wardrobes; Bureaus;
Tables; Chairs; Washstands,
Bedsteads, Bedding, and Mattresses,
Lounges, Crockery, Cooking Stoves, &c.
2 tubs Butter; 1 bag Coffee,
61 pair Cotton Cards, &c.
se 6 Redwood & Keach, Auctioneers.

div3.head: By Alexander Nott, Auctioneer.
div3.p:
Household and Kitchen Furniture &C., at Auction.--Will be sold at auction, at 10 o'clk, Monday, Sept. 8, at the residence of C. J. Krausz, on 17th street, in rear of the Old Market, his entire stock of Furniture, &c., embracing a large lot suitable for a snack-house.
Also, the Furniture of his private house, consisting of Bedsteads, Beds, Mattresses, Tables, Chairs, Wardrobes, Cabinets, Looking Glasses, Crockery and Glassware, Stoves, &c. Terms cash.
se 6 Alex. Nott, Auct.

div3.head: By Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.
div3.p: seven Handsome Building Lots on die and Jackson streets, in the town of Manchester, at Auction.--We will sell upon in premises, on Wednesday, the 10th day of September, commencing immediately after the sale of Mr. James Turner's property, say at 5½ o'clock P. M., four handsome Building Lots in "Todd's Tenement," fronting 30 feet each on Biddle street, and running back 120 feet to an alley 14 feet wide.--Also, three Lots on west Jackson street, having the same front and depth.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by trust deeds.
se 6 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.

Two Handsome Building Lots on the East side of 17th street, near to the Old Distillery, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises on Thursday, the 11th day of September, commencing at five o'clock P. M., two handsome building lots, located on the east side of 17th or Valley street, and adjacent to the old Distillery.--They front together 50 feet, and run back 120 feet to an alley 20 feet wide.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 4 and 8 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 5 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.

A desirable Framed House and Lot on Mill street, in Adams's Valley, at Auction.--We will sell upon the premises, on Thursday, the 11th day of September, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., a very desirable Framed House and Lot located on Mill street, in Adams's Valley, and near to the new workshops of the Virginia Central Railroad Company.
It contains four good rooms, and is particularly adapted for a small sized family.
The lot fronts 40 feet and runs back 200 feet.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 4 and 8 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 5 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct'rs.

div3.head: A very desirable Brick House on Mosby street, Union Hill, at Auction.
div3.p:
--We will sell upon the premises, on Tuesday, the 9th day of September, commencing at 5 o'clock P. M., a very desirable Brick House located on Mosby street, Union Hill, containing four good rooms, kitchen, and other conveniences, and now in the occupancy of Mr. Vaughan.
The lot is of the usual size.
Terms.--One-third cash; the balance at 6 and 12 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
se 4 Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Aucts.

div3.head: Three houses and Lots, and several Vacant Lots, and four acres of Land, in Marx's Addition to Manchester, at Auction.
div3.p: --With a view of removing to the country, I will offer for sale at public auction, upon the premises, on Wednesday, the 10th day of September, commencing at 4½ o'clock P. M., in the following order, several valuable pieces of real estate, viz:

list.item:
1st.
The two large, framed Tenements, located on Hull, or Main, and Allen streets, containing several good rooms, and are adapted for medium sized families.
The lot fronts 46 feet, and runs back parallel with Allen street 165 feet.

2d.
The large, two-story, framed House and Lot on Hull street, nearly adjoining the Provost Marshal's office, containing several excellent rooms, together with the usual out-buildings.
The lot fronts 66 feet and runs back 165 feet.

3d.
A square of Land, containing four acres, in Marx's addition, upon which is an excellent spring.

div3.p: Terms.--One fourth cash; the balance at 6, 12, and 18 months, for negotiable notes, with interest added, and secured by a trust deed.
James Turner.
Jas. M. Taylor & Son, Auct's. se 2

div3.head:
By W. S. Berry, Auctioneer.
(Farmville, Va.)
div3.p:
Auction Sale of Valuable Medicine.--Will we sold at public auction, on Wednesday, September 10, at 11 o'clock, an invoice of valuable Medicines, being the stock of the late Thos. Hickson, dec'd. Invoice and Medicine can be seen at any time between this and the day of sale.
Mary Hickson.
se 4--5t* Ex'x of Thos. Hickson, dec'd.

div3.head: Administrator's Sale of Valuable property.
div3.p: --On Tuesday, September 9th, (if fair; if not, the next fair day,) I shall sell at Belmont, Nelson county, Va. within five miles of either Arrington or Nelson Depot, a large quantity of valuable personal property, consisting in part of
10 Horses, 8 Work Oxen,
10 Milch Cows and Calves,
50 head of Hogs,
5 Wagons,
1 Concord Buggy,
1 ton Peruvian Guano,
3 tons Ground Plaster,
Wheat Drill, Rake, Fan,
Corn Sheller, Plows,
Harrows, Shovel, Hoes,
Axes, Grindstones, &c., &c.
Also, the entire School Furniture, among which are--
80 Blankets, 57 Check Counterpanes,
50 Mattresses, Pillows, Bolsters,
Sheets, Pillow Cases,
Towels, Table Cloths,
Bedsteads, Tables, Stoats,
Basins, Ewers, &c,
Much White Graniteware,
Knives and Forks, Spoons,
Kitchen Utensils, &c., &c.
Terms.--For all sums under $25, cash; over $25, a negotiable note, hearing interest from date, with approved endorsement.
Francis H. Smith.
Adm'r of Dr. Gessuer Harrison, dec'd.
au 30--tds
